body.p: To His Excellency Govr Thomas E Bramlette:

The undersigned jurors who tried & witnesses who testified for the plaintiff in, the case of the Commonwealth of Ky versus Joseph Conrad for keeping a tippling house at the present term fo the Harrison circuit court, state that he was found guilty under the following proof: That some time last in March 1864, Elijah McDaniel & others came to the distillery belonging to the defendant & wanted to buy a quart of apple brandy: that deft refused to sell to be drank on the premises: that after repeated importunities, defendant consented to sell & did sell McDaniel ^& several others each a quart of^ a quart of apple brandy, on condition that it was to be taken off his premises to be drank, but that McDaniel & the others, after getting the brandy, & contrary to their agreement & the protest of the defendant, drank the same only from 5 to 10 steps from the defts distillery. Deft was fined $60. & cost. The undersigned believe that the letter of the law required the jury to find the deft guilty; but that it is ^a^ case in which you ought to interpose & remit all that portion of the fine over which you have power. They pray your interposition to remit that portion of the fine & as in duty bound &c May 3rd 1864

p.note: the persons to whom it was sold were on their way to ^& from^ a sale in the neighborhod & got the brandy at Dfts Distillery
